results.title: Julien Donkey-boy
results.creator_credit: Independent Pictures, Scott Macaulay, Robin O'hara, Cary Woods and Harmony Korine
results.brief_description: The first American entry to Dogma 95 is the second feature for Harmony Korine who faithfully embraces the manifesto by improvising scenes, shooting digitally, only using available light and minimal post-sound. “Julien Donkey-boy” also utilizes the loose narrative (or non-narrative) structure of his controversial feature debut “Gummo” (1997), offering a series of randomly connected vignettes in the life of an ‘average’ American family. Ewen Bremner plays the title character, a child-like schizophrenic whom we first see as he murders a young boy, then promptly goes home and forgets about it. Korine serves up an uncomfortable portrait of family life for Julien: a dictatorial father who is prone to wearing a gas mask (played with glee by director Werner Herzog), his sister, Pearl (Chloe Sevigny), who is pregnant with Julien’s baby and a young wrestling obsessed brother (Evan Neumann) whose father pays him to dress up in his dead mother’s clothes. The films loose style and roving camera makes it feel uncomfortably documentary like at times, while the films grainy, ‘no-frills’ look produces some surprisingly haunting and beautiful images. Cast also includes Joyce Korine and Chrissy Kobylak.

results.title: Julie, your best just isn't good enough
results.brief_description: Julie left school early and as been in and out of jobs for four years. She has been unemployed for tem months and is willing to take any job. She talks about the dole, what she does with her money and about her parents.
results.title_for_label: Julie, your best just isn’t good enough

results.title: Julie Stafford's taste of life : the video
results.creator_credit: Martin and Rosenthal Pictures, AAV Australia, Chris Weir and Malcolm Dwyer
results.brief_description: Best selling cookery writer Julie Stafford invites you to prepare a variety of mouth-watering recipes for breakfast, lunch, children’s meals and dinners for everyday and for special occasions. Julie also gives a brief outline of healthy foods to eat, shows how to choose and store them and gives an introduction to some common herbs. A weekly menu planner is included.

results.title: Julie Julie
results.brief_description: Julie was sick of living in Broken Hill, so she bought a motorbike and left to ride around Australia. The film shows part of her journey and illustrates the sense of freedom and independence of young people breaking loose.
results.description: Julie was sick of living in Broken Hill, so she bought a motorbike and left to ride around Australia. The film shows part of her journey and illustrates the sense of freedom and independence of young people breaking loose.

results.title: Julia: critical moments in teaching (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Calvin Productions, United States. Dept. of Health, Education and Welfare, David Gliessman and Don G. Williams
results.brief_description: Julia, a naturally retiring child, becomes withdrawn in class. The school psychologist tests her and finds she has a hearing impairment. He recommends keeping Julia in her present class. Her teacher is suddenly confronted with the realisation that she has primary responsibility for Julia’s education. What steps should she take to help her?
results.creator_credit_for_label: Calvin Productions, United States. Dept. of Health, Education and Welfare, David Gliessman and Don G. Williams

results.title: Jules Verne
results.brief_description:
Jules Verne had three passions in life: the sea, music and freedom. The passion for the sea started during his childhood in Nantes, in the Quartier de l’Ile Feydeau, filled with memeories of explorers and slave traders. Destined to become a lawyer, Verne is sent to Paris where he begins to write. His writings are highly influenced by the industrial revolution and the belief in the power of the machine to transform the world.

Credits: Director, Jean Vidal ; writer, Yolande Cassin.
Cast: Daniel Ivernel [narration only].

results.title: Jules et Jim = Jules and Jim (Cinemascope Print)
results.creator_credit: Les Films du Carrosse, SEDIF and Francois Truffaut
results.brief_description:
The story of a menage-a-trois in the years around World War I is distanced by the narrator who makes the viewer continually aware of the artifice involved in its telling. Truffaut drew on incidents in his own life in developing Roche’s novel in a personal way. He identified Jim with Roche and Jules with himself. Their discovery of Catherine is symptomatic of the confusion between art and life which pervades the protagonists’ lives. The narrative, punctuated by cinematic allusions, is marked by a wide range of techniques and rapid shifts in mood from pathos to whimsy. Also avaiable on VHS and laserdisc.

Credits: Director, Francois Truffaut ; writer, Francois Truffaut, Jean Gruault ; photography, Raoul Coutard ; music, Georges Delerue ; editor, Claudine Bouche.
Cast: Jeanne Moreau, Oscar Werner, Henri Serre, Marie Dubois.
